author: Benton Frisse
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2021
review_content: Look, I'm not going to lie to you all... am I the pinnacle of physical fitness? Nope, I slam my fair share of Taco Bell weekly. Can I slam a whole row of Oreos in one sitting? You bet I can. But, I DO like to do things that get my heart rate up. I'm also a sucker for anything that Nintendo cranks out that really mixes up the normal gaming experience.I love this game; it's fun, unique, and definitely a workout. I've been playing this on my lunch break all week. I'm sore, it makes me sweat, but it's also a great game. it tracks your calorie count, how your workouts compare day-over-day, etc. Excellent option for someone who likes to game, but hates the idea of going to a gym.
title: Unique, fun, and a great workout!

author: Corry H.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2021
review_content: This truly is the best way for "gamers" to get exercise. No longer will raging at your teammates in COD or Rocket League be your workout! I played the adventure mode, which is what you'll mainly be doing anyway, set on beginner difficulty (10 at first, then 13. For comparison sake a "normal" difficulty workout is 25.) as I am overweight and have very little stamina for working out and such. Yeah this thing kicked my butt instantly. Between doing 125 squats in 10 minutes, which sounds easy but to me it wasn't, and yoga exercises that was difficult. Now over a month later I'm not exactly looking better but I have lost weight and I have more defined muscle mass. I'm NOT "pro wrestler jacked" or anything but I have muscles where I had nothing but fat.
title: This thing will kick you butt on day 1!

author: My Paradigm
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2021
review_content: I am WAY more fit since buying this game and I 100% recommend it to anyone. I have never liked to run in any setting. There have been times when I've enjoyed other types of exercising, but before buying this game I was doing 0 mins a day. Between the great visuals, the fun story and mechanics and the customizable aspects, I immediately changed my mentality and became very enthusiastic about fitness. I saw physical changes in my body (inches lost, muscles showing) before I lost any weight, but I eventually lost a few pounds too. You can be as casual or intense with this as you want. The main story is broken up into short levels, and during the levels you can pause or stop and go back if you need to. You can also repeat levels you like. The 'battles' are turn based (they wait) and you can go at your own pace doing the exercises.My boys just turned 7 and 4 and they are literally underfoot sometimes, but I am still able to get it done. They both play some too! The 7 year old doesn't like exercise, but enjoys this and can do everything on his own. The 4 year old can do the jogging courses. My husband had surgery and could only intermittently (and lightly) use this, but still enjoys it.It took me around 75ish days to complete the story line. After that, 'new' levels open up, which seem to be repeating the original levels but with new dialogue and obviously level appropriate mobs.Custom Mode allows you to create a fitness list of exercises that you can save and perform any time. It's a more 'focused' workout and you can change the number of reps and string different styles of play (rhythm game, jogging, specific exercises for targeted areas). Quick Play has preset challenges, minigames and targeted sets to choose individually. There are other cool features but I don't use them much yet.More of my favorite things about this game:-It's user friendly and flexible-cool visuals-tracks your time moving, calories burned, and km run and shows it in real time-has an avatar performing the exercises at the same time to give you a visual help-has sounds and verbal prompts to indicate when you're not doing an exercise correctly-rarely 'forces' you to do specific exercises and does have a help function if you are unable to-can be challenging but isn't a beat down-allows you to pause and walk off at any time-allows you to customize the difficulty as you go (which will increase/decrease reps)-slowly introduces gameplay mechanics (not overwhelming)I wish this game had continued support and DLC. I'm a little afraid I'll get bored but so far I'm still enjoying it. I recommend watching youtube video demos if you want to see some of the gameplay.
title: Day 120 and still going

author: Jenny Swart
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2020
review_content: Seriously, due to quarantine I almost didn't get my hands on this.  But I managed to get one as they came in stock, and let me tell you, it's been a game changer.I was working out at home before I lost my job, but then I was depressed and no matter what I tried, I wasn't sticking to it.  I remember the days of being a teenager and using DDR to lose weight, and it worked.  That's because it was fun.  THIS IS FUN!Challenging? Yes.  Do I sweat like crazy? Yes (I also use a sweat waist band that is amazing) and best of all, my joints don't hurt like I'm 60 years old.  No seriously, I was in so much pain from doing nothing, and now I feel great.  So, definitely worth it, but DON'T BUY FROM SCALPERS!! NOT WORTH IT FROM THEM!!
title: Quarantine Workout

author: Beaslybub
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2021
review_content: People raved about this game so I got it for a family member as a gift. I was pretty disappointed in the game once we started. This is one of those expensive and fancy games that sounds good in theory but will end up on the floor of your closet.User interface: somewhat complicated and hard to adjust to. Shifting up and down on menus with the ringcon only is a PAIN (it always goes to the bottom or top option automatically because it is too sensitive).Graphics: no matter what personalized look you choose, you won’t see it in the cutscenes. Then why bother changing your avatar’s hair color, etc.? Otherwise, graphics are fine.Workout Level: the “moderate” workout is actually pretty exhausting (I workout on an exercise bike 3-5x/week at moderate tension) and felt lightheaded/had a headache after 15 minutes of the moderate levels. I STRONGLY suggest you start at casual.Gameplay: starts out fun because of the novelty of the game (jogging through a fantasy world and doing squeezes and moves to “jump”, then fighting bosses with turn-based combat in which you perform about 5 different exercises—just one at a time) but VERY quickly this becomes tedious and I mean within a few levels. There just isn’t enough variation to make this game interesting after you’ve played the first few levels. Someone pointed out this isn’t a game for people who are sedentary gamers who want to exercise, but is more of a game for moderate fitness people who just want a hint of entertainment with their workout. But the problem is this isn’t even an aerobic workout because you stop after certain points and switch to other moves during boss battles, between levels having to watch cutscenes, etc. It’s very frustrating.Personally, I expected more when I saw the rave reviews. Yes, I’ve only played for the first few levels, bit and I’ll drop it down to casual and see if that makes a difference, but as of now, this game seems really overrated and overhyped. Again, your family will probably play it for awhile during the holidays after they open it and then never play it again, and it’s too expensive to make that worth it.Spend your money on an Exerpeutic foldable exercise bike that faces the TV and you’re far better off and more likely to get your exercise in than playing this tedious game.
title: Overpriced and overrated, tedious

author: austinandroid
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2019
review_content: We love the game so far!Got it as a gift for my girlfriend and I and we've had so much fun after only playing for a couple hours!The game is genuinely challenging and I thought I was in decent shape, but boy was I wrong.The best part is the exercises in ring fit adventure are things that I don't usually do in the gym. It's easy to just get into a gym routine, do biceps, chest and back on machines or dumb-bells and not much else. With Ring Fit Adventure, my body is quickly sore and exhausted because it makes me do a bunch of things that I never do in the gym, obviously a lot of resistance type workouts with the Ring-Con and difficult squats and such as well.Really awesome especially for me, I work from home and even though we have a gym nearby, it's nice to just hop over to the TV, get a workout in then come back to work!I'd recommend making sure you can see your TV well from a Standing position, as our TV is mounted fairly low so when I do the exercise my neck naturally wants to bend downward toward the TV but that is bad posture, so keep this in mind and try to keep your posture correct.Would recommend this game to  those who find it boring to go to the gym, or who want to add some variety and exercise to their daily routine!Excited to see what games come next for the Ring-Con!
title: We Love it! Very Challenging and a simple fun way to exercise, and adds variety!

author: masYmas
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2020
review_content: ..but Holy Moly this 'novelty' had me panting and sweating like Richard Simmons trying to keep up with Shaun T's Insanity workout!!The initial setup went smoothly, brief instructional video and software setup, easy peasy.The first thing I tried was a test to see how many times I could squeeze the resistance ring in one minute, easy right?!...WRONG!!! By the end of the minute I was sweating and I could feel all of my sedentary rarely used muscles starting to tighten up all over my upper body!Needless to say it was humbling and humiliating at the same time..The Ring resistance band gives surprisingly good amount of progressive resistance and will help you get a fairly good upper body workout. Not a replacement for free-weights and gym machines per se but you can definitely get toned with the Ring Fit.The games are engrossing enough to keep your mind occupied while actually getting a really good workout.The Ring Fit Adventure is a great alternative to the Gym during this unfortunate time and circumstance we are all facing.As with any home exercise equipment or your Gym membership YOU need to use it and stick with it until it becomes a habit! Don't let your Ring Fit collect dust like that BowFlex sitting in the corner of your garage, Use it and Lose it(lbs that is!) while having a great time!!
title: WHOA!! I thought this Ring thingy was a 'novelty'...

author: Matthew J. Kreglow
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2021
review_content: Worth the price, especially considering how expensive exercise equipment is. I like how it has story mode (which is surprisingly compelling) as well as a mode where you can put together your own exercise regimen. The level up system is very intricate, and power ups are neat and fun to collect, though some level grinding will be necessary to unlock everything. But that just means more exercise, which, for the most part (see drawbacks in the next paragraph) is a lot of fun. Plus, the community for this game (the sub reddit especially) in addition to the game itself are very supportive and helpful. The graphics are also beautiful, particularly during sunrise and sunset environments. The enemy selection is cute, being modeled after gym equipment.Drawbacks are that some of the exercises don't register with the motion controls at times (mountain climbers, deep squats, and basically any stuff that requires the joy con leg strap tend to have some difficulties), so that can get frustrating, especially if you're trying to 100% the game. Some of the minigames are fine (destroying crates by blasting air from the ring con is very satisfying), but others are a mixed bag (aerochute is a good workout, but not much fun, and squattery wheel is finicky). The rhythm game is a fun idea, but the execution is just okay, not amazing, but fine for a couple of rounds before moving on to a different exercise. Also, the game tends to reuse entire levels a lot, so there is an issue with environment variety. But at least the enemy selection is varied, so it doesn't feel like a slog to get through repeat levels.While the issues above seem overwhelming, they don't detract from the experience overall. Despite a few flaws here and there, this game is a whole lot of fun and makes exercise feel like fun rather than an obligation.
title: Ring Fit Adventure, though not flawless, makes exercising actually fun.

author: IAWL
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2019
review_content: This game is fantastic! We got it on release day and we have played it every day since. We started with the mini games to learn the technique and find the difficulty level that was best for us. I’m 50 years old and my son is 16, and we both love it. The adventure mode is difficult at times, even for me and I’m someone who has had a professional trainer in the past. Wow it really works the muscles and you’ll feel it the next day. Unless you’ve got the ring set to easy (or whatever be lowest level is). My son normally sits playing BOTW or the new Dragon Quest for switch, but this has got him off the couch - active AND fighting enemies. Each world has new challenges and you can earn more attack modes which are different workout moves. I’m definitely looking forward to getting some new clothing later in the game because I’m not a fan of orange. :) And we also like the “free” mode or whatever it is called where you can use the ring to do arm of leg work and it keeps track (handy while watching a tv show) then when you turn your switch on and go into the game you select which player gets awarded the points you earned from your reps. So much more to come, I know we’ll be enjoying this for a long time. If you love video games that are challenging and want to get a good workout in with room for improvement and challenges, this so for you. Even the cool downs are geared toward what workouts you chose in your attack modes. So if you did more arm work, the cool down will focus on your arms more. I could go in and on about this game and we’ve only had it 5 days! It’s out of stock as I write this review but get it as soon as you can!
title: Awesome workout for kids and adults!

author: Paula
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2021
review_content: I really enjoy playing this game, and I wasn't sure about it at first after having played the Wii Fit game and the Wii Active and being a little less than impressed.I bought this game because of the reviews, and also because my gym started getting lax with the covid guidelines and I no longer felt comfortable going.For some background on me: I'm a pretty athletic person and I like to stay active. I've been a runner for about 10 years, and I have been doing CrossFit for 1.5 years. I saw a lot of reviews of beginners really enjoying this (and I will say if you set to an easier difficulty, I think this is excellent for beginners). But I set it to a level 26 difficulty, and selected that I wanted an "intense" workout and damn. That's definitely what I got.I love the game portion of it and how you complete different levels in each world, and the monsters you come across on the way. It's so much fun to run through the different levels and collect ingredients and coins, and to be challenged on a specific body part depending on the monster's color.And the boss battles are fun, too! This game isn't just exercising for the sake of exercising, you have to have strategy, too and some aim (which I am not always the best at) but it makes it feel like you're playing a game of Mario or something similar.And this workout burns about just as many calories as an hour of Crossfit does (when I do it for a full hour) according to my watch.Overall, I'd highly recommend you get this game regardless of your fitness level. I suggested it to a friend of mine who's completely sedentary and needs motivation to workout and she's really enjoying it. It's very adaptive and you can make it as difficult or as easy as you want to, and you still get to move your body and get healthier which is the most important thing! Buy it, you won't regret it.
title: I am pretty impressed

author: Eva
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2020
review_content: I decided recently I need to start exercising, but have had a ton of trouble figuring out necessary how to exercise, what works well for me, and to actually build a habit of it. As of writing this, it's in the thick of the COVID-19 pandemic, so going to the gym is out of the question and can't get a personal trainer, so this seemed like a great idea for an adaptive and fun exercise regiment.And it is!What I've heard most about Ring Fit is it's kinda tough, which is true starting out. However I've been doing this for four days and have been able to increase the difficulty a little and comforably double my workout time today, so I feel it's built me up very quickly (not that I'm going for longer than 30 min ever, or that I'm suddenly swol). When you start out, it asks you about your age and weight, how much you exercise already, and how much of a workout you want, as well as gauges your push and pull strength, to give you an appropriate workout regiment. It also frequently reminds you to take breaks, hydrate, and to not over-do it. I did over-do it once, so I just hit the "cool down" button, which brings you to the finishing stretches, as well as shows you your progress and a brief lesson on how to maintain a healthy lifestyle.The Pilates ring is very sturdy! I was worried it would be kinda flimsy as it's a video game pack-in, but it's clearly meant to handle the abuse for years to come. The leg strap could be bigger in my opinion; I'm not a big person at all, but have very large thighs, and have trouble getting it to fit nicely. Above all the motion controls are very responsive and accurate, to the point I nearly forgot to mention it as you're never given any reason to think about it; it's just smooth and accurate. Also really love how the IR sensor on the right joycon reads your pulse! It's a little wonky, usually takes a couple tries to get it to read a steady pulse, but really cool none the less.I haven't ventured much past the main campaign, but it has A LOT of bonus material. There are several minigames(my favorite is Thigh Rider which, as you can guess, targets your thighs), sets to workout various areas, virtual jogging paths, a "multitask" mode which you can workout on your own with the ring without using the screen and it records your progress, and targeted workouts for specifit muscle groups. Haven't yet dipped into the Custom Workout, but intend to in the next few days.I absolutely can't recommend this enough to anyone who wants to get into working out and is having trouble finding the motivation. I have ADHD so creating new habits can be really hard, so it's often necessary to gameify things like this so I can be motivated to continue with it. Trouble is it can be a little too fun sometimes and can be hard to walk away from when you get worn-out, so absolutely make sure to supervise any children who might be using this (or housemate with ADHD lol).I feel this is a very good tool for working out, and comes at a very reasonable MSRP (got mine for $70). Hope this review helps, and I hope this tool helps as many people as possible!EDIT: I lost a pound after a week of use! Granted I've got a fast metabolism (when it works right, got Hashimoto's disease so not always the case), and I've adopted a high-protein diet, so results will vary. This is exciting for me because, largely due to factors caused by the pandemic and chronic illness, I'm about 10 pounds overweight. Very glad to know what a "good workout" is and to see results!
title: Can't recommend Ring Fit enough

author: Deborah L Closson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2021
review_content: I am a 66 year old women who has not been active in quit sometime.  After I retired found myself on the couch doing nothing. I saw the advertisement for ring fit and thought what the heck let’s give it a try. It’s been over two months now and I consistently play for 20 minutes,  twice a day, 5 out of 7 days.  Overtime hope to achieve 60 minutes twice a day. Pretty good considering when I began 5 minutes of playing kicked my butt.For the first 3 weeks I just played the main game. Then I discovered quick play which I like better as more exercise in less the time. Not one to ever enjoy running I am drawn to the jogging quick play and consistently set goals to eventually make it through all sections at the highest and hardest level.If you are like me, and don’t want to exercise in public and want something different to motivate you, I would recommend ring fit. Other then me being a little slow at figuring things out and how to maneuver within the system I have not had any problems.
title: Gets me off the couch

author: Broke College Student
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2021
review_content: For the first few days, yes, this product is amazing and makes working out really fun and engaging regardless of level but slowly it becomes more repetitive and more boring to the point where the game is even worse than just going to the gym. Here is why:1.) on the main adventure game you will consistently have to do a set of exercises that are exactly the same and results in the same thing on screen. For example, you're only allowed to select 6 different basic exercises per level and once you select that you will be doing these 6 exercises for 20-40 minutes depending on what level you are on.2.) Again, only 6 specific exercises allowed over the 40+ exercises in the game. Why cant it let us choose from all 40 exercises and instead restrict us to just 6.3.) Each level is just exactly the same thing but just shorter or longer. I remember the XBOX connect game xbox adventures and that was so interesting because you were always doing something different and fun. This is just running in place seeing the exact same scenery.4.) Workout to the music: they really need to expand this selection. My current selection is basic theme songs and even some melancholy songs which are not interesting or easy to dance to. Obviously this is not "just dance" on switch but I expected better.5.) overall the game does teach you good posture but horrible technique for in-game exercise moves. For example squatting, for entry players and experienced you will have to squat a lot but the game doesn't really teach you the correct form at all which is VITAL for the exercise to work properly. If you just bend and sit like the game teaches you, your form will be way off.
title: Can get boring incredibly fast

author: Allen I.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2021
review_content: I played this for 2 weeks and actually really enjoyed it immensely. Until the pain in shoulder began.Here's the unfortunately reality of this - you WILL get injured if you're not VERY careful. It's a game, so it might seem ridiculous to some that a game will A) give you an intense workout and B) can injure you in any capacity. Just like a "real" workout, this WILL make you sweat and be intense at times.The game is almost TOO reliant in making EVERYTHING a workout, without checking in enough to see if you're OK. You squeeze the included tension wheel too much in too many different ways to really be safe (and you need to squeeze it A LOT, for example when you're creating items) especially for a beginner just getting into working out again. Also, it doesn't take any injuries into account. For example, when my shoulder began hurting badly (turns out it was a rotator cuff injury from playing this game) there was no way to totally avoid using your shoulders or arms. I also have bad knees, but the game doesn't take that into account when judging your form. It's not your typical "do your best until you can do better" it's "do exactly the way we show or else you'll likely fail". This was disheartening as I couldn't properly do squats as deep as they wanted so my "moves" always failed, and the enemies would defeat me.  Don't get me wrong, I liked pushing myself, but the game forced me into pushing too hard. Eventually I stopped because my injuries were getting more severe. And honestly I was too afraid to start up again for fear of further injury.If you're more experienced at working out, this can be a great supplement. And it's FUN don't get me wrong. It just doesn't account areas you might have an injury in, especially in the arms.
title: Fun until it's not

author: Ewan Grantham
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2019
review_content: My first level with this I have to admit I was surprised just how much of a workout it really gave me. I had confidently set it to medium difficulty, expecting to maybe be breathing heavy after 10 minutes. You can imagine my surprise when halfway through my watch was letting me know I'd just finished 5 minutes of strenuous workout.More surprising, to me anyway, was that even though I was exhausted at the end, I was also eager to get back on it the next day. It hasn't quite become a daily routine yet, but I think it most likely will get me there!
title: Almost enough fun to make me want to exercise

author: Sarah
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2021
review_content: I bought this and was expecting it to be kind of gimmicky but hopefully give me at least a bit of a workout - but oh man, it's so much better than I expected. I absolutely hate working out - I'm in my 20s and have the joints of an 80-year-old - but I've tried just about every gym class, workout video and exercise known to man to try to get me into the habit and nothing ever stuck. After one day of RFA, I was hooked; I've played every day for two weeks and don't see myself stopping anytime soon.RFA is definitely silly, but it knows it's silly (the enemies are barbells, yoga mats, etc.) and it's just super enjoyable to play while also pushing you to your limits. Of course, you have to push yourself - you can pretty easily cheat the system if you want, and at the start of every workout you have to consciously decide whether you want to increase the difficulty or stick where you are. If you really want to make a lifestyle change and enjoy traditional Mario/Yoshi games, you can really get a lot out of RFA. Give it a shot!
title: Awesome exercise for gamers

author: BigGinge
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2020
review_content: So, during the first couple of months of lockdown I’d put on a bit of weight on top of a bit of excess weight I was already carrying. (6’2” and 126kg).I started a diet to get myself down to a target of 100kg. Weight dropped off quickly  until about 2 months in where I plateaued at 108kg. It was obvious that calorie counting alone wouldn’t be enough for me to hit my target. With gyms shut and knowing little of what exercise routines would work for me I thought nine oils give this a try.After 10 days of ‘playing’ this game alongside  my calorie counting and I’ve broken through the 108kg barrier to 104kg. Not only than body fat percentage is down and muscle mass is on the up. I already feel so much better day to day having started regular exercise. I’ve now bumped up the difficulty a couple of notches and can really feel the difference.I used to find exercising a chore; which is why I didn’t do as much as I should. Playing this game removes the chore from exercising. I commit to around 40 minutes of exercise a day whilst playing this and the time flies by. There’s plenty of variation and new exercises  get thrown into the mix to add to the variety.For those who need motivation to get fit or lose weight I cannot recommend this enough. If you don’t own a Nintendo Switch then get one just for this.
title: Perfect lockdown workout : lots of variety and lots of skill levels

author: Gabriel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2020
review_content: Due to the pandemic, I haven’t been to the gym in months. My exercise routine has been little more than 1 mile swim once a week, pushups/pull ups and the occasional walk or run.I was skeptical when I purchased this, but I needed something and the reviews were promising.By the end of my first hour, I was exhausted having gone into my first session unprepared. The next day my legs were sore as if I had just ran for 7 or 8 miles, so I took the day off and got back to it.The game is fun. A lot of fun. So much so, that an hour flew by and I kept looking forward to playing again.If you don’t try to cheat the game, increase the difficulty as you get stronger, the game will challenge you and get you into shape.Is it going to replace the gym? No. Will it increase your cardio, help you lose or maintain weight while you can’t hit the gym? Absolutely.You can take the game up a notch by purchasing ankle and wrist weights, supplement the game with push ups, pull ups and crunches if you desire.Highly recommend it for beginners to experts, especially in the midst of this pandemic.
title: Came away surprised

author: Samuel Clemens
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2021
review_content: If you're out of shape and get into this, I would recommend going on the easiest difficulty and pacing yourself. The game gives you plenty of warnings but once it starts, it doesn't stop. You can always increase difficulty but the game does ramp up as you go through the adventure mode. You can also take breaks between levels. I do wish the game had a more explicit instant stop or pause (like on most treadmills) but it's designed in a way where it's really pushing you to your limit.I don't know if this is going to help more athletic people or people who already regularly go to the gym (if they can). More specifically, this game will immediately aim for your knees, quads, and hamstring muscles with squats, yoga poses, high knees, leg lifts, and jogging in place. You'll also get good cardio because, as I mentioned, once a level starts, it keeps going to the end of the level (levels are literally designed like you're racing through an obstacle course). There are RPG-like fights where you work your core and arms and, thank god, stop running in place. But honestly, it's better to do planks and push-ups. I would mostly get this game for cardio and building leg muscle.
title: Kicked my butt and kept going

author: Amelia B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2020
review_content: I've had Ring Fit Adventure (RFA) since November, and I'm approaching level 100 in the adventure mode. Like any new thing, I was much more eager in the beginning at the chance to get healthier than I am now. The game doesn't push you to keep coming back to play. And while some people may be disappointing, I have found it much better for myself in the long term.RFA is much more of a game than past fitness Nintendo games have been. Instead of holding a wiimote and using a balance board you have a legstrap and the ring-con (pilates band) to create the movements of your character on screen. It has a basic story and plays on quite a few RPG tropes, but does so in a way that makes you get that little bit of escapism that can keep your mind from associating the game from a hard workout when you're pushing to get those last set of knee lift combos in. You still know you're exercising, but you're doing it towards a tangible goal of finishing a level, defeating a boss, or completing a sidequest for a cool reward.One of the big things about RFA is that it doesn't push you to keep going. It'll offer an alarm to set a routine, but doesn't bug you past the first mention. After about 10 minutes of active time (upon finishing whatever level you're on) it'll offer that you've done well for the day and can stop if you wish. It reminds you not to push yourself to exercise if you're feeling sore (believe me, as a sedentary person before this you likely will be). This lets you really know that you are in control, and that for me, the game understands that you can be busy or not in the right form to jump in for another day. I don't feel bad for missing a few days, because I know when I jump back in the game will drop me in where I was and let me continue pushing forward.I do think you'll get a heck of a lot more out of the game if you collaborate with friends. I'm definitely motivated to keep going when I see my friends post their summary sheet detailing their exercise time and calories burned for the day. We bemoan over the dreadmills and squat swings. We celebrate each other's wins. And it's honestly great to have.I'm also happy to have an alternative to a gym membership. Instead of feeling bad for not going somewhere enough due to paying a monthly fee, I have this sitting in my living room, fully paid for up front, ready to do a quick workout after a long day at work. As someone who has struggled with wait, bullying, and lack of physical exercise growing up, knowing I can be comfortable in my home and get a great workout is huge. It hasn't turned me into any kind of gym rat, but I can definitely feel my body getting a little stronger and more in shape, which makes me very happy.tl;dr The game won't push you to exercise, but it's gorgeous and well thought out to let you do it at your own pace whenever you're ready.
title: A great tool to help you exercise

author: Mikey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2021
review_content: I wish I could give this 10 stars! I hadn’t worked out in a long time. I quit smoking and gained 30 lb. I bought this on a whim and it’s honestly changed my life. It’s gotten me on a good routine, very dedicated to my workouts. I do at least an hour every day on this. (I just hit Day 30 and Level 100!). It makes working out FUN. author: No

review_content: Overall, I'd give this five stars. My whole family of five has played and enjoyed it. It definitely improves our fitness. I do have a few nitpicks:1. The motion-based menu controls are kind of terrible, and the menus themselves aren't great. I mostly use the joystick and buttons, because the motion controls are so confusing. author: Mor and Tookie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2021
review_content: I've only played for 2 days, but I'm enjoying this quite a bit.The game play is pretty easy:You jog through various lands.  You squeeze on the ring fit to "air blast" things near you (ie: open a door, break a box).  You pull on the ring fit to "vacuum" things (ie: bring coins to you), and also to jump (you blast downwards for this).  Most of the time, you don't actually NEED to do this, but I find it fun to try to collect all of the items so I could level up sooner.I find the direction controls annoying.  For example, if something is located at the 10 O'Clock position from me, it's hard to judge where to point the ring fit in order to actually blast that exact direction.  I'm only on day 2 though, so it's quite possible that I'll get better at this as time goes on.The game also has monsters that you have to beat.  This is done with "exercise contest" in an RPG style.  You can either choose the attack that you wish to use, or use a random one.  You will then need to do a set of that chosen exercise, and the monster's health bar will decrease.  You then choose the next attack.  Most monsters need at least 2-3 different exercises.As your level rises, you gain more hearts, more attack damage & defend power, and more exercises to use in the battles.My 8 year old son is also enjoying this game quite a bit.  The game chose our starting strength level automatically based on our ages, some easy questions (do you exercise right now or not?), and how strong our initial "squeeze" of the ring fit was.  As far as I could tell, the strength level is the amount of reps you have to do for each exercises in the monster battles.I hate exercising, but this feels more like a game and I don't really think of it as hard work (even though I do feel sore after using it)I recommend this to anyone who wants to work out, without feeling like they're working out.

author: Nathan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2020
review_content: As a means to ease people into fitness or as a supplement to those already into fitness, Nintendo has built on what they did for Wii Fit and produced probably the best fitness 'game' out there!The meat of the game is centered around an 'Adventure Mode' where your protagonist and 'Ring' (the in-game avatar for the included 'Ring-Con' accessory) go up against an antagonistic muscle-man dragon named 'Dragaux'.  Gameplay is centered around running through levels, collecting coins and other items, interacting with a wide variety of decidedly fitness inspired contraptions, and fighting enemies in a turn-based-RPG style battle system.Battles and simple movement through the world has you doing tons of different types of exercises, from squats and knee lifts, to planks and scissor kicks - from tricep kickbacks and bow pulls, to tree pose and warrior pose.  There's a huge variety of exercises to do and the game systems encourage you not to just stick to ones you find easy, while at the same time having a very comprehensive and customizable 'assist mode' which allows you to skip anything that you may not being to do.  The whole game really does a great job of adapting to your current level of fitness.  Before you start, the game calibrates your running speed, your pushing and pulling strength, takes your age, weight (optional), how fit you are compared to your age group, and how intense of an experience you want and works out an optimal difficulty for you. At the lowest difficulties, even those who do not work out at all will be able to keep up.  And at the highest difficulties, those who work out quite a bit will find their heart rate elevated.  The game also slowly encourages you to increase the difficulty, but has enough of a gradient that increasing the difficulty by one level isn't too bad.  One month later though, you realize you're doing twice the number of reps for an exercise as when you started and it feels really good.The game's RPG elements are light compared to other non-fitness games, but are surprisingly expansive for a fitness game.  You have a level up system, multiple-enemy hitting attacks, type weaknesses, recovery and buffing items, debuffs, a skill tree, metroidvania-esque movement unlocks, towns, clothing options, and more!  And most impressively, everything is unlocked at a slow enough pace that even if you're not familiar with RPG games, you will not get lost.Pretty much everything in the game is inspired by fitness - You have enemies based on kettlebells, springboards which fling you through the air after a squat, and fitness related puns apleantly.  The whole presentation is a bit cheesy, but is quite charming and funny.There are a few points where the game falls short.  For one, tutorial messages get repeated A LOT.  Motion control detection is by-in-large fantastic, but there are a few exercises for which the detection seems to be consistently off.If you're on the fence about getting Ring Fit Adventure, know this - It is a wonderful motivating device to get you moving.  If you've ever spent a ton of money on a gym membership as part of a New Year's Resolution, only to stop going before the end of the month, this might just be the game for you.
title: Fantastic fitness experience

author: Hannah Weiss
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2021
review_content: I had been struggling with inactivity a lot during the pandemic, and I cannot express how grateful I am for this game! This makes exercising fun for people who may have never enjoyed typical workouts before--the platforming style, ability to choose your exercises, and incorporation of strategy make for a really enjoyable experience. The ring is high-quality, and the devices are impressively accurate in picking up motion. I occasionally need to adjust the leg strap, but that's a very minor inconvenience.Things that make this great:1) Fun! The music, cute characters, and mini games make this truly enjoyable.2) Accessibility---it takes very little to get going. You're at home--you don't need to put together a full workout outfit or worry about how you look. I also appreciate it's option for apartment living with the "quiet" mode--instead of jumping around, exercises can use more bouncing motions to avoid too many loud noises.3) An actual workout! The very first day, I was surprised to find that I was really working up a sweat. But, that's the point! I can sign on and do some fun mini games for a warmup or get into a real groove and workout for an hour. It's definitely more strength-focused than cardio unless you really get into the jogging in place.4) Reinforcing and positive--I smile every time it tells me "Your sweat is so shiny and beautiful!" I appreciate how long the game actually is--I'm on day 24 and know that there are still months more of the adventure. It celebrates the little successes every day, from hitting a new record on a mini game to a benchmark number of reps on an exercise. It's also brilliant in that you level up quickly (I usually aim for 5 levels a day), and leveling up leads to good rewards with skill points that allow you to increase your stats.The pricetag may be a bit intimidating, but I think that it's absolutely worthwhile for anyone looking for a fun, rewarding, and sustainable way to get more active.
title: Wonderful Fitness Game!!!

review_content: Writing this review from Costa Rica, 8 months after I began playing this game. I'll rephrase that, exercising with this game changer. I'm halfway through my end goal and I will do my best to update this review around March 2021, hoping to bring bigger numbers :)Back when I started, I played the game from 3 to 4 times every week for between 10 to 15 minutes of effective work out time (not to be confused with total session time, which was around 25 to 30 minutes). Combined with a new eating plan from my nutritionist, I began losing between 2 to 3 pounds on a monthly basis.I'll admit it, I got tired of the game after 6 months of constant weekly use and began looking for alternative options to do exercise  like jogging outside. At first, the jogging was going very well, but I soon realized my weight loss started slowing down. After that, I came back to the game and I'm glad I did! I now do between 18 to 25 minutes of effective exercise having sessions of around 45-50 minutes.I haven't finished the main story, I'm on world 21 and have read there are 23 worlds, so I should be completing it within the next 2 weeks.The purchase of this game was completely worth it, specially now that most of us should try to stay home and avoid places like the gym.It's fun how my body starts asking me to play this game during the week, it's an amazing and a fun exercise. I feel you're really in control of how much you have to push yourself and the feeling afterwards is very rewarding.I thank Nintendo for this amazing game, I love the story, the progression system, game play, graphic, battles and I hope that they'll at some point release a DLC with more of it!
title: A game changer

author: jacquelyn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2021
review_content: I have been playing this game for 1 month now, and I LOVE IT! You get so involved in the game and beating the bosses that the time flies by and your getting a great workout at the same time. I am a 60 year old women and am finding I want to play it everyday( which you can). It gives you the main adventure which consist of different levels in each world where you jog through and collect coins and items for purchases like smoothies for power, extra life,etc.  The game also lets you play as tough or easy as you need. I have gained so much muscle in 30 days and have lost 6 lbs too! There are mini games that you can play when you just want to fool around. There is also a custom workout section where you put together your own specific exercises you would like to do, all in the same fun exercises you perform in the adventure mode. The bosses are funny too! They have names like Abdonis, who is king with abs. The ring itself is a great tool as you have to squeeze it for almost everything so it’s a great chest workout all the time. You need this game for a fun workout anyone can do.
title: So fun and a great workout!

author: S
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2021
review_content: I've got young children and we have a very strict screen time policy in our household. iPads are for FaceTiming the grandparents and the computers are for school or very infrequent amazon wish-listing before birthdays :)This is the first time we've been able to really relax the screen time policy. The kids love playing with the Ring Fit (and I like it too - but holy cow it's a tough workout to be sure!) and we don't feel the need to police the TV because they're being really active. The only rules we had to create surrounding the Ring Fit were: 1) at least ask before starting (usually the answer is yes), 2) if you're in the room *watching*, you have to also be doing the exercises as if you're playing (I bought a couple additional pilates rings for cheap that my kids use), and 3) take turns. It seems very re-playable as well, but I do hope they release more games for it.I do have concerns about the longevity of the ring, it seems to be losing it's circular shape with how much we're using it. If it gets bad, we might have to contact Nintendo to ask for a replacement.
title: Amazing product from Nintendo! Turn screen time into fun exercise time!

author: Mike_Wazowski
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2021
review_content: So this will actually give you a decent workout if you put in the effort.  Im not a fan of running in place, but when everyone is stuck in the house due to covid quarantine you do what you have to do.  If I had young kids this is a good way to get them off of the couch when they are stuck inside.  I'm an adult and it makes it more entertaining to try to stay in shape from your own living room.
title: Actually made me sweat

author: Morgan. L
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2020
review_content: Game is great!I spend about 8 to 9 hours working my job on weekdays, I'm usually pretty burnt out by the time I get home.The great thing about this game is that you can set the exercises and workouts that you want to do (if you don't have time for the main story), whether it be squats, yoga poses, jogging in place, stretching out deltoids etc. I can spend anywhere from 5 mins to an hour playing this game!The workouts provide a nice sweat and I always feel like I've accomplished a lot even if i play for a short time.The story is basic, but very cute. The ring con character is like your training partner, he pushes you to complete your sessions and is very encouraging, love the guy!The ring con controller is very sturdy, it feels like the harder I stretch the harder it fights back.While i don't think this game will replace going to an actual gym, it's a great starting point for people who can't invest in much time (or money).Definitely recommend!
title: Great workout alternative to the gym!

author: Claire Hopper
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2021
review_content: I love this game. Absolutely love it. It doesn’t make you do intense strength and cardio, yet gives you just enough of a workout where you will immediately feel the effects well into the next day. You can change the difficulty levels on what challenge you’d like, and you can also choose between jogging in place or fast squats (Silent mode), which is what I normally do since I workout in the second floor of my house.I don’t think it’s expected for you to become ultra fit after months of playing this game, although I have seen people do a 100-day challenge and lose over 30 pounds by playing for 1 hour each day. Do I want to do that? Nope. But I will more than likely play this 4-5 times a week for 30-45 minutes on the “intense” setting, while still doing light exercises because I just want to maintain a base of fitness.In conclusion, your Honor, I’d say spend your hard-earned cash on this if you want something to get you off the couch and be submersed into a game that is both challenging and hilarious, as your goal is to defeat an insanely buff Dragon in a singlet.
title: I Can’t Get Enough of This Game!

author: Kimberly W.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2021
review_content: I’ve really been impressed with how much fun this is to play. After the day is over, it’s pretty easy to get in a quick 20-25 minute workout playing through the adventure mode. I know I haven’t made it through all of the game modes, or really changed the workout challenge levels, but it is a nice option for other members at home.I’ve been continually surprised by how many different workout techniques are possible with a ring and a leg strap. Obviously this doesn’t won’t replace weight workouts, and cannot replicate excellent cardio, but it is altogether a great way to break a sweat and stay toned.
title: Impressive

author: Henry Dryden
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2020
review_content: Had been talking myself into buying this for months until I finally purchased it back in November. After a little under two months of owning it I can happily say it's been worth every penny - as long as you are consistently playing of course. I am someone who is physically disabled with fibromyalgia, therefore normal exercise like walking outside or going to the gym is nearly impossible to me, not to mention I am also in college, so schedules can be tricky to navigate. I don't push myself any further than I need to, as the game is encouraging in a healthy way that doesn't shame you for needing extra assistance or a break. I can feel the physical difference in my strength at work and about my daily life when I take care of more physical tasks, which makes me feel mentally better as well.
title: Amazing addition to a daily routine

author: Monique Millan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2019
review_content: The second I found out about this game I absolutely did the pre-order and it came to me the day it released. As soon as it arrived I set it up plugged in super easy set up profiles that up immediate start to gameplay. Very simple to use and user-friendly, both my boys are obsessed with this game. Definitely worth the money it’s priced that, because in the long run if you really think about if this is way cheaper than a gym membership. Although the amount of calories it says it burning is a lot less than what you feel, I feel like it’s worth every penny and time and effort to put into it because it makes you active. You definitely are in for a good sweat!!
title: Long-term benefits to a money sucking gym membership!!

author: Sam
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2019
review_content: I love this product so much. My wife and I bought it because we wanted a way to keep in shape during the winter months. We don’t like gyms and don’t have room for a treadmill so this was a perfect choice for us. All we have to do to work our is move our coffee table over and strap in.The excercises are intuitive and the controls are easy. I think even most nongamers could use it. The gaming part is one of the best things about it. Unlike other previous excercise games this once has a story and acts like an rpg. When I work out I really feel like I’m playing a game. The story is simple but even a simple story can give you the right motivation to do the workout. It’s easier to excercise when it just feels like you’re enjoying a game and beating bad guys rather than working out. It’s nice to level up even when I can’t see the results of the workout in my body right away.It’s inclusive. There’s different levels of difficulty. There’s a lot of accessibility options. There’s even a way to workout while your Switch is in rest mode. I guess I only wished it counted my steps too! Maybe in a future update it could.
title: A great way to excercise for nerds and non nerds alike!!!!!

author: Phil
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2020
review_content: Finished all 23 worlds in 5 months. Played intermittently in the first 2 months, then virtually every single day for about 1 hour since COVID work-from-home period. Mostly in max "difficulty level" -- maximum repeats of each move per round. Total net exercising time a bit over 50 hours. The net exercising time is typically about 60% of your game time. Say you play it for 1 hour, you probably get 35 to 40 minutes of net work time.Effect: reshape of my abdominal is the main outcome. From an average fat guy, to someone that you can see the shape of abdominal muscles. Weight loss is not significant if you only want to rely on ring fit. I lost 6 pounds during the period, but you have to combine with careful diet.Also a lot of fun for home parties.In my opinion, the best investment you can get on any gaming. It may be unethical to raise the price due to its supply-demand unbalance, but if you hesitate on the $200+ price in COVID period  and missed the 3+ month with it and sit home and gained weight and fat with other stupid games, I think you will regret.
title: Great great for home gym

author: Pinx
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2020
review_content: I am pleased with the variety of this game. I researched it before purchasing. It's been very helpful to give me something in which I could work within a pre-defined structure, or make a structure to target specific needs. I will say that the pulse-reader on the controller is useless, so I have to rely on my slightly inaccurate fit bit to see where my heart rate is.I like that they incorporate a mix of body-weight exercises, and resistance training with the ring con. They do not have enough yoga positions.  The mini games are decent, but some of them like thigh rider are awkward with the ring con.I'm a decently fit person, and I feel like I can get worn out doing this. I have my ring con strength set to "hard", and have from the start. I have gotten sore muscles from working out with this, and I am a little skeptical about the estimated calories burned. I think that is important is consistency, average heart rate, and length of a workout sessionYou can get a decent mix of strength-training and cardio/fat burning while using this game. I would recommend having a cushioned yoga mat and shoes on, because doing this even barefoot on a mat, or barefoot on the floor is going to be really hard on your feet and ankles. I noticed they have some kind of assist/handicap for some exercises, but I have not tried them, and don't understand how they work.Another thing they could do is incorporate a better cool-down/stretching routine, but it's okay for me since I have a professional background that has emphasized stretching. I know where to fill in the gaps for my workout.I use this in conjunction with going for walks, free-form dancing, and other types of exercise so I don't get bored. With Ring Fit Adventure, I now have a lot of variety, so working out feels more like play, and less like a chore. I would not recommend people with heart troubles or balance issues to play this game. You can start out very slow and just do mini games, and not do any of the jogging in place stuff, so if you're not someone who has a decent level of fitness already, you are still in control of how deep you dip your toes.4-stars for how great this is, how it enhances my access to exercise, and for the couple of things I mentioned that I feel could be improved. It is not a waste of money at all if you are able-bodied enough to use this game!
title: I am pleased with the variety. There's a couple of things they could improve.

author: TheDave
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2019
review_content: This game is amazing!  I was never into Wii Fit, or Wii Fit U games and glossed over them years ago as it didn't seem interesting.  The way that they advertised this and the quality/design of the accessories and software is freaking awesome this go around, and it also helps that motion sensory tech has come a long ways too back from the Wii days (among other gadgets).I consider myself a fairly in shape guy that's 6'0 and average around the mid 180s in lbs. I have an active job and I started using this to supplement my workout routine and I tell you what, this kicked my butt when I told the game the current max difficulty of 26 in the game wasn't tough enough for me in the first level of the adventure mode so it got cranked up to 30 today for stage 1-2 and 1-3 (the boss round).I cried manly tears of sweat today and the game asked me if the new difficulty was challenging enough...So, while I completed the challenge I decided to go back down to 26.  I can't handle 30 right after doing a work out before hand for very long/without breaks, so I think I'll work my way up there!Anyways, I definitely recommend this game.  It's a fun way to get in shape, mix up your routine, lose weight, or w/e.  It definitely takes the monotony out of every day exercises and introduces some stuff you may not think about day in/out.
title: Jumped in, got knocked out...Awesome stuff!  Don't skip leg day.

author: Cheng G
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2019
review_content: Easy to set up the ring. However, it took quite a long time to create a new account, sync personal info, and go through the whole preparing process especially when every time a new friend came to my home and played the Adventure game with me. The quick games are funny and competitive. They’re more suitable than the Adventure game for being played by a group of friends.Don’t worry about the strength and difficulty of using the ring to practice your arm. As long as you are not a “gym guy”, the ring exercise is hard enough to make your muscles sour. Trust me!
title: Initiative interactive design and worth to try!

author: Z. Cherry
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2021
review_content: With winter, running is a bit hard to do in subzero weather and the exercise bike can get a bit boring. Books on tape are fine for that, but doesn't really keep you engaged. This game is pretty well designed and I was shocked by how much of a workout you can get from it. That ring can be easily squeezed flat, but the game is more about a LOT of reps than straight up strength. Of course running in place is more like skipping rope and doesn't help with stride, but keeps your heart going and calories burning. Also still works the calves quite well.All in all, a nice supplemental exercise routine that can't replace free weights or actual running/cycling, but still accomplishes general fitness. Also, not intimidating, so good for someone who is trying to get into fitness. Also track pretty well, so you can see your accomplishments. For such a cheap price tag, it's a great product.
title: Surprisingly fun and well priced.

author: Tay
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2021
review_content: Don't underestimate this as a workout just because it is a "video game". I workout about 2-3 times a week. This thing whooped by booty...literally.PROS*Timed workouts*Entertaining*Variety of workouts*Scheduling*FunCONS*Wish I got it sooner**This comes with game, ring-con and leg strap.
title: Underestimated...

author: David Hartman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2021
review_content: I feel weird but I can't deny it when I say this game likely saved me life.It's helped me not only stay healthy with exercise but it's also helped with the depression and motivation. I'm finally moving forward with my life and this was a big catalyst for that tho not entirely responsible.On a lighter note, the music design is phenomenal and it's and incredibly positive experience.By far the best deal on a trainer you can buy, $80 (one time purchase) for a physical trainer is an absolute steal
title: Best $80 physical trainer u can get

author: manthejohn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2019
review_content: The ringcon and leg strap included are well built and sturdy. The leg strap is stretchy and can accommodate most leg thicknesses.I'm having a blast with the adventure mode so far, it offers a varied and intense workout session high in calisthenics reps to get you sweating. Depending on how strong you are, the difficulty level can be adjusted to suit all levels of skill.Because of the nature of adventure mode, you'll find yourself challenged with new calisthenics and yoga techniques added to your routine, some of which I've enjoyed practicing and trying to master my form on. If you have a certain exercise equipped that you reeaally don't like doing, you can replace it with another exercise and sort of craft your own unique routine.The mini games also offer an exciting diversion from doing calisthenics and yoga all the time. They really get you moving and take full advantage of the six axis motion sensors in the joycons.If you've never exercised before, this game is the kick in the butt that will get you started off enjoying fitness. If you're already very fit, this game is a great diversion from traditional exercise and can be supplemented into your routine easily.If you're looking to bulk up or gain weight, look elsewhere, regular gameplay will build lean and defined muscles long term. However, I've been switching off between weight lifting and ring fit quite comfortably!
title: Great daily exercise for anyone.

author: Jezi
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2021
review_content: Seriously.  I'm an over 40 overweight gamer who has been hunting for an exercise type I don't despise or get bored with for years.  I haven't had fun with anything exercise related since I stopped doing dance classes because I couldn't find anything I liked aimed for adults where I lived.  Zumba doesn't count, it sucks.Now?  I don't want to put this damn Ring down.  It's my friend, my best bud, the one that gets my heart racing and my skin sweaty. We play games, run through hills and valleys with careless abandon in search of adventure and to save the world.  We are inseparable!Real talk though, this game is a ton of fun. I've started booting it up while at lunch from work and I have to make myself stop to go back to work instead of looking forward to when lunch is over so I can stop.  The fitness calibration before you start the game is actually useful.  Then you set your level after that and it actually adjusts the games to match what you want and are capable of.  My out of shape behind can do this stuff, work up a sweat, and feel accomplished all in one.  Better than any living coach I've had and no judgemental eyes on me cause a fat body has invaded the gym.  If you are very overweight you might need an extender on the thigh band, but that's a $9.99 investment that works like a charm.  The mini games and quick sets that target areas of the body are fab too.  Worth every penny.
title: It's so much FUN!

author: Betty C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2020
review_content: Waited three months to get it because it was in such demand. So worth it! Such a good game to get moving while at home. Many ways to customize the workout and the timing. Fun mini games. Cool creative exercises with the ring across different areas (arms, abs, legs, yoga). Another good thing is how good technique is enforced. You get higher points for lower squat or higher knees for example. Before each exercise, you have to be in the right setup so you never have to rush. Scenic and adventure like feel while running around in the maps (waterfalls, jungles etc).
title: Worth the hype

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2020
review_content: Pros:- It helps to workout.Cons:- It arrived the shipping box open(Someone definitely tried to open). Fortunately, everything was still inside, so I didn't file a claim.- It's hard to locate the menu and to go back to where I want.
title: Pros and cons

author: Megan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2021
review_content: I'm the kind of person that turns on the workout DVD and then sits on the couch to watch it play out. However, let me tell you, when my legs are killing me but I only have 8 more squats before that monster is defeated you best believe I finish those 8 squats! I accomplished a level the other day and in the summary at the end realized I had jogged a mile almost without even realizing it! I could have probably kept going except my hubby wanted a turn.I'll never not recommend this game!
title: Best Workout Coach ever

author: Griffin Wiebel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2020
review_content: After a couple of sessions, I'm taking a break to say this is some of the most fun I've had breaking a sweat. This simple RPG game has been kicking my butt every time I turn it on, but I keep coming back because it is just plain fun.The box comes packed with the game, ring, and leg strap. The foam handles on the ring are nice and plushy and pulling/pushing on the ring feels great while the ring remains sturdy. My multiple sessions have not wore this ring's integrity, which was one of my concerns. When you start the game, an informational video autoplays and does a great job informing you how to set up the ring and strap.The game itself is a RPG runner, where your go from the start to the goal by running in place. On your way are enemies which, when running into them, will start a workout session battle. Here, you will choose from many workout
title: The Most Fun I've Had Exercising

author: CP
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2021
review_content: A game I kept only for a month. Played it. Tried it. Didn't care for it. My young teen and kid nieces didn't care for it. They used it for PE and wasnt really dedicated to it. I even lost interest and I'm pretty fit. It's a good idea for a good short time. But the adventure portion was boring and repetitive, cheesy, rated Y. There's a lot of taking and time in between the workouts to make sure your form is prepared, not proper. So even if you're doing the movement right, it wouldn't count your rep. There's a lot of slow moments with all the story play which is boring. I raised the fitness level all the way up and found it challenging to work up a sweat but after seeing the total calories burned I said forget this waste of time. Playing 1hr and only 200 calories. Buh bye. I bought a Peloton instead and everyone seems to love this much better.
title: Super boring and takes forever to burn any real calories.

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2019
review_content: It's amazing how easy it is to game-ify the human brain and forget you're working out, and this is by far the best shot anyone has taken at really making it happen. Already both of my roommates are using it, and everyone loves the thing. Wii Fit was a silly distraction that was good enough to convince me to do some extra workouts, but this thing is serious--using the Pilates ring was an inspired choice. We'll be using this for a while, and it's well worth every dollar.I've been steadily losing weight with a few different programs over the last year, and have lost about 40 lbs; my usual routine now is to do a 5x5 three times a week, and to run ~20-25 minutes twice a week. I figured this would be amusing enough to convince me to do a sixth day, and I can already tell it's much better than that--this won't replace my 5x5, but it definitely might replace my runs, at the very least for the snowy season. It keeps my heart rate around 120-130, it combines yoga and pilates strength exercises, and (most importantly) it gets you to just forget you're working out altogether. Somehow the minute-to-minute gameplay is just so weirdly compelling you don't want to stop. I've completely blown out this week and I *actually wish I could go play it more.*The story mostly stays out of the way (other than the random fitness jokes), which is a good choice for now, but I massively hope this sells well enough to justify Nintendo doing more with it and not treating it as a second thought. I'd much rather have the chance to build a character in one of Nintendo's actual properties (really, *any* of them), and I hope they realize exercises don't have to be 1:1 with your character's actions. Give me a fitness Metroid expansion and I will play the thing forever.
title: Forget you're even working out

author: DP
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2020
review_content: I’ve been working out regularly for the past decade. It was getting stale even though I varied my routine, my playlists, and my weights. When Ring Fit came out I was skeptical, but got it after seeing some YouTubers play it.It’s great! As a gamer, I forget I’m working out and just feel like I’m playing a video game. The worlds in the story mode give you varied exercises on a daily basis, and the difficulty adjustment makes it accessible for everyone. It’s surprising how tired squeezing the ring can make you.My only gripe is that the leg strap loves to slide down, but I’ve solved that by tucking my shorts back through it to keep it in place. I’ve heard of people safety pinning it too. I’m reluctant to take a star away for that, though, because I think it’s still worth every penny, especially if you’re struggling to get on the fitness train.
title: Most Fun I’ve Had Working Out In A Decade

author: Josh
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2021
review_content: You're gonna like this review:So before the covid pandemic lots of gym facilities were closed. Also at the time (yes, gym rats also play video games!) I did have a nintendo switch lite, and idk why I bought that originally since it is so limited so once scalping calmed down I bought a nintendo switch at the nearest target. Best purchase ever! Now, lately Monster hunter rise came out and I became so addicted, haha. But addictions from the nintendo switch calls for nintendo switch solutions! So i considered ringfit, because right next to monster hunter rise in the menu is ring fit and lemme tell ya: they make exercise so fun. You want to keep going and get every tid bit like coins, doing critical hits with attacks and boss battles. Need something if you can't go to the gym and have a switch? Definitely recommend this game. All levels of fitness abilities should try it! Don't believe me? I'm a relatively fit person, went to the gym 4-5 days a week but then I unfortunately just became lazy being at home all the time. When I did this, i puked, yes puked. The real deal, lol. Try this game out!
title: Former gym rat before the pandemic approves!

author: Leah
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2021
review_content: (Hopefully this is ok.) If you are like me and have children that love to play video games but you feel need more exercise or can't get outside to play during the wet and cold of winter then I recommend this game if you have a Nintendo Switch. RingFit Adventures is a video game so the kids love playing it but it teaches them health facts and they work on running in place, arms, abs, legs. It has them do moves that focus on different parts of their body as well as yoga while they accomplish tasks and beat monsters. My kids fight over who gets to do play first everyday since getting this. It puts my mind at ease because even though they are playing a game they are still working out and learning. I have even played the game myself to try it out and man was I sore the next day. (My 6 yr old and 8 yr old play it)
title: Fun and good work out! Great for kids or adults that like video games.

author: J. Gregory
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2020
review_content: I’ve been meaning to try to do yoga for my whole life, basically.  But I’m not athletic in the slightest and it’s intimidating to start.All you need is some open space (carpet or yoga mat for the floor moves), and a chair for sitting for a few of the mini games. A corner of most living rooms will work.They walk you through set up and game play and all the moves, so don’t feel intimidated.  There are some moves that could be impossible if you have bad knees, but the core, arm, and ab moves are generally easy.Anyway, I look forward to playing everyday, even a few minutes a dat after a few weeks have left me feeling a tiny bit sore but stronger.  Game play is engaging, the storyline leaves me wanting to keep going, and the characters are funny.I just hope they come out for more games using the ring con!
title: Doing yoga... for fun? Yes, please.

author: Gadget
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2020
review_content: Ring Fit Adventure is the newest healthy lifestyle game that Nintendo has released. It is a great workout video game for anyone to play. In the box it’s Two accessories, the Ring-Con and Leg Strap, that measure your real-world actions and help turn them into in-game movements. The design of characters is really good. The scenery in each level is amazing. Adventure mode have 100 levels in over 20 worlds.  It’s a polished, fun game that feels like a real workout. I can say Ring Fit Adventure surpasses Wii Fit in features. It offers a more challenging workout.
title: Excellent Nintendo Switch Game

author: Ashley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2019
review_content: This game is better than expected/imagined!  It's not only fun and interactive but you truly get a workout.  The variety of settings make it possible for different players with more or less energy/skill.  You are not forced to do things you physically cannot but challenges are available for those that want to push themselves.  The game seems to know when you are struggling and reminds you to drink water, take breaks, move slow - on the other side of that, if you are preforming well it suggests making things a little harder.  I was surprised that the cooldown feature changes depending on which exercises you did the most of - that's great!  The game lets you complete goals, earn rewards and there's even a mode to play together in mini-challenges.  I really hope they continue to make more of these amazing games!
title: Finally!  Workout while playing Switch

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2019
review_content: I love video games. Which means I hate bad games. However, this was a pleasant surprise! It’s honestly a GREAT workout when you find your difficulty level, and even if you’re still searching, you can get a good workout by playing more levels!I love that there’s stretching (however basic) before and after you start, and the game does such a good job encouraging you for your progress. It reminds you always to listen to your body, watch your posture, and stay hydrated, which SO many workout programs forget to do, especially games.The ring and strap are very sturdy and in my experience they sync up fantastically well with the joy cons! My ONLY concern with the ring is that with such sweaty hands as I have, I don’t know how to clean the grips :lI love this game. It’s given me such a welcoming platform to get back into working out. I never feel like I’ve wasted time, honestly, I feel like I’m not spending ENOUGH time on it, I’ve been getting fatigued after 20 minutes of exercises. I always walk away with a pleasant exhaustion and the stretching keeps most if not all soreness at bay.I’d recommend this to anybody and everybody looking for a guided home workout. I HATE gyms (social and body anxiety) and working off of videos and lists never really did it for me. Somehow, this kiddie adventure keeps me going, no matter how annoying Ring’s voice is. Tip, the game’s “trainer”, has helped me a lot to watch my posture and get my rhythm. It almost feels like an actual class in a gym.If you need something to get you going, go with this. You won’t regret it. Worse comes to worst, you now own a sturdy workout ring to flex and pull into some beefy new shoulders of yours :)
title: 21 year old single female and this is fantastic for jumping back in!

author: The doctor
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2021
review_content: This is actually a really fun and well done exercise experience. It allows you to play through a what is essentially an RPG on rails. Full of enemies and xp and ways to spend coins to upgrade your characters. While at the same time it requires you to do all sorts of workouts with and without the included Ring band. The motion controls work quite well. There are also a bunch of extra mini-games for when you want to slow the pace down. And you’ll want to pretty quick. This game can be a real workout with jogging, squats, sit-ups, leg lifts, and a lot more. ( there is an option to replace jogging with squats if you don’t want to shake the place you live in). The resistance Ring band is easy to use and super durable. Controlling the game uses the Ring band and a leg strap that take advantage of the motion controls in the joy-con controllers. If you want to actually get some exercise in your home or even out of it considering the portability of Nintendo Switch this is definitely worth checking out. It gets my full recommendation.
title: A lot of fun and a great workout

author: Nina M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2019
review_content: The game is overall very good. It's cheesy, but it's cute. The exercises are unlocked as you go, so some of the negative reviewers clearly didn't play much of the game. Part of the problem with unlocking as you go is, older exercises end up doing less damage. Some very good exercises, like squats, are left by the wayside for a while, until they can be leveled up to do a comparable amount of damage.I am not in very good shape, but this game is helping me fix that. I play very consistently, which it encourages. It's entertaining enough to make me want more, even though the story and dialogue are cheesy.
title: Cheesy, but fun

author: Jack Zhang
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2020
review_content: When I first got this, I didn't know what I was going to get from this game. I was very surprised that the ring actually resists and tracks how hard you press on it. The leg strap is one of those standard straps with a pouch that you would get for your iphone while jogging. The strap goes on your left leg and the ring sits in your hand. There are different resistance levels that can be set in game to make the game easier or harder. I would heavily suggest having a set of indoor shoes to be able to jog in place or else the running in place could cause some pain to your feet.
